variable in cases that require reference semantics.

inlineContent.text: class declares the programmatic interface to objects that manage a modifiable array of objects. This class adds insertion and deletion operations to the basic array-handling behavior inherited from
NSMutableArray is “toll-free bridged” with its Core Foundation counterpart,
In addition to the provided instance methods, such as
There is typically little reason to subclass
. The class does well what it is designed to do—maintain a mutable, ordered collection of objects. But there are situations where a custom
object might come in handy. Here are a few possibilities:
stores the elements of its collection. You might do this for performance reasons or for better compatibility with legacy code.
Acquiring more information about what is happening to the collection (for example, statistics gathering).
In a subclass, you must override all these methods. You must also override the primitive methods of the

abstract.text: An object representing a static ordered collection, for use instead of an
constant in cases that require reference semantics.
An object representing a dynamic ordered collection, for use instead of an
variable in cases that require reference semantics.
Initializes a newly allocated array.
Removes from the array each of the objects within a given range.
Sorts the receiver in ascending order as defined by the comparison function
Adds the objects contained in another given array to the end of the receiving array’s content.
Replaces the objects in the receiving array specified by one given range with the objects in another array specified by another range.
Removes the object with the highest-valued index in the array
Removes the objects at the specified indexes from the array.
Empties the array of all its elements.
Removes all occurrences in the array of a given object.
Sorts the receiver using a given array of sort descriptors.
Exchanges the objects in the array at given indexes.
Inserts a given object at the end of the array.
Removes all occurrences within a specified range in the array of a given object.
Evaluates a given predicate against the array’s content and leaves only objects that match.
Sorts the receiver in ascending order, as determined by the comparison method specified by a given selector.
Removes from the receiving array the objects in another given array.
Sorts the receiver in ascending order using the specified options and the comparison method specified by a given
block.
Replaces the object at
with
Sorts the receiver in ascending order using the comparison method specified by a given
block.
Removes all occurrences of
within the specified range in the array.
Returns an array, initialized with enough memory to initially hold a given number of objects.
Inserts the objects in the provided array into the receiving array at the specified indexes.
Removes the object at
Inserts a given object into the array’s contents at a given index.
Replaces the objects in the receiving array specified by a given range with all of the objects from a given array.
Removes all occurrences of a given object in the array.
Sets the receiving array’s elements to those in another given array.
Replaces the objects in the receiving array at locations specified with the objects from a given array.
Removes the specified number of objects from the array, beginning at the specified index.
